titleStmt.title: An entry from the Journals of Hensley Henson

sourceDesc.bibl: Edited from the manuscripts in the custody of Durham Cathedral Library.

p.hi: The hard frost still continues, but there are reports of a thaw in Scotland.
I wrote at some length to
thinking it perhaps advisable that he should know where I stand in this difficult juncture. He will not be pleased to learn that I am little disposed to blink the essential issue.
Herd send me another immense telegram:

Many thanks for letter. Fully appreciate your point of view. yours is a splendid idea. Please do not think of withdrawing proposal. The book you contemplate is vitally needed, and only you can write it. Go right on with book at once. Am coming north Tuesday. Can I call at Auckland Castle 4 p.m.
Evidently the gushing knave was rather startled to find that I didn't rise to his ''prophetic'' nonsense!
I wrote to both the Archbishops, Lords Durham & Scarborough & others sending them good wishes for the New Year: & then I cast up the account of 1927.

. I have come into closer relations with the Archbishop of Canterbury, and the fact has tended to raise my estimate of his Grace's character. My advocacy of the Revised Prayer Book has alienated many who assumed too rashly that I held with their Protestant fervours. The controversy raised by
strain on my personal friendship with
and I can see that the rift is destined to grow wider
. In the diocese there is only
the completion of the repair of Escombe church to be recorded in the credit scale

, save perhaps for a slight improvement in the matter of Ordination Candidates. The diminution in the number of working clergy continues, and the fact is certainly telling badly on every part of the church's work.
In fact, the diocese is running down, & the situation moves quickly towards a deadlock
